info.title: SUSE Best Practices Strategy and Plan
info.subtitle: Internal Only

sect1.title: Background
sect1.para: In every organization, a lot of hidden IT knowledge and experience exists. This is also the case for SUSE, no matter which product you are looking at. For every product and solution, there are subject matter experts that have profound know-how and skills.

Our Consultants, Sales Engineers, Supporters and also Partners work with our customers on a daily basis to implement, strengthen and fine-tune our solutions, to find the best options how to install third party software on our operating system, or to get the most out of our customer’s infrastructure. Many proof of concepts and customer projects have been conducted. And many of them are at least partly documented. Also, many Technical Information Documents (TIDs) are already written and probably somewhere published on the webpage.

Our own infrastructure department has to solve challenges, or already found easy ways to implement certain set-ups, which might occur similarly or might be helpul in a customer set up. One of our engineers might have found a certain solution to address a common problem in a repeatable manner, which is not yet documented.

This kind of knowledge or information is usually "buried" on a personal laptop or probably on a team server. In addition, most of these documents are not in a shape that they can be published as are, because they refer to customers that we are not allowed to name, or include some information that needs to be removed before published.
In short, a huge part of the knowledge available in our company is not publicly available for our colleagues, partners or customers, and if publicly available in any form, it is usually hard to find.

sect2.title: Mission
sect2.para: The purpose of the &sbp; is to change this situation. We want to make existing knowledge and experience available to a broader audience, and we want to promote it via a recognizable series of documents. We want to ensure, that our colleagues that

sect2.title: Vision
sect2.para: With the &sbp;, we even go a step further. We aim to introduce a new series of documents that provides reliable technical information and establishes a new “Go-To” source for the usage and implementation of SUSE products and solutions, also in combination with third party software and hardware, similar to the famous IBM Redbooks (http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/).
Our goal is to make the &sbp; so prominent that at a certain stage volunteers knock at our door to contribute, and feel honored if we pick their proposed topics for our SUSE Best Practices papers.

sect2.title: What Exactly is a &sbp;
sect2.para: In contrast to the SUSE product documentation which mainly guides through SUSE software installation and usage, the series of SUSE Best Practices papers provides installation and implementation experiences.

This means a &sbp; paper describes a technical scenario / solution that is not covered by the general and extensive SUSE product documentation. Such a scenario can also include third party software and implementations (partly) done by partners.

While the SUSE product documentation is usually delivered in parallel with a new product, the &sbp; usually will not adhere to newly launched products, but to products already introduced to and established in the market.
Usually the scenario /solution has already been conducted in a real-life scenario at a customer's site. It can include – but is not limited to:

listitem.para: a specific, non-common setup
the installation of 3rd party software on top of a SUSE product
the implementation of a multi-part solution
a step-by-step procedure
a newly tested procedure
a proven process or methodology

sect2.para: &sbp; should be replicable and adaptable, they aim to save time as they use existing knowledge for further replication, and they should be sustainable and easy to update.
Depending from the complexity of the topic, the &sbp; might differ heavily regarding their length. Typically a &sbp; document should be between 5 and 30 pages in length.

sect2.title: Target Audience
sect2.para: The &sbp; usually target existing customers that need to work on a specific solution or solve a concrete technical problem. We address mainly system administrators that have to set-up and implement the technical solution in their companies. In limited cases, the &sbp; might also be from interest for technical architects or technical support or helpdesk staff.

sect1.title: Definition of Whitepapers, Success Stories, Case Studies, Blogs
sect1.para: SUSE also provides written material to customers which is perceived by our customers as part of the SUSE documentation material, but is created under responsibility of the Marketing teams. To avoid any confusion between the purpose of the SUSE Best Practices and Marketing documents such as whitepapers, success stories, case studies, and blog entries, the next few paragraphs focus on the definition of these documents.

The target audience for the Marketing documents usually are technical or business decision makers, and they generally target potential customers that do not yet run SUSE products, or customers to whom we want to upsell additional SUSE products. Marketing documents are mainly used for Demand Generation. In Marketing language, Demand Generation means: creating an interest in our products and services, and building and nurturing key prospect and customer relationships for the long term.

Usually, you will find two different kinds of whitepapers at SUSE. There are technical whitepapers. They provide a technical overview and are mainly product focused. Here you can find high level technical information, for example important technical features or technologies are explained and translated into their business benefits. These papers are written by Product Marketing, but if required, the Doc team supports these whitepapers with proofreading, or editing. And there are Business whitepapers. These papers provide a business overview of a product or solution and focus mainly on the business value. Business whitepapers are completely done by the Marketing teams.

A Success Story must include the customer name within the story. It is usually only 1-2 pages in length and explains how a customer successfully implemented our products in their company and environment. It contains high level details of a customer project, direct quotes from the customer, and paints a short picture of the project – from start to finish. It covers the problem, solution and results from a business perspective, and reveals why our customer chose our product(s) for their project.

A Case Study provides more details and specifics than a success story. In addition to the above, it showcases the how - not in the meaning of an instruction how to implement a product, but how a solution was delivered or how the solution works in the customer’s environment. Case studies deliver much more in-depth technical information versus a success story. At SUSE, case studies are a minimum of four pages, and they must involve tangible measurements of results, such as cost savings or increases of efficiency. Their main purpose is to describe how a customer did benefit from the implementation of a SUSE product or solution by translating the technical information into measurable business results.

SUSE also provides a platform for a Corporate Blog https://www.suse.com/communities/blog. A Corporate blog is a blog that is published and used by an organization as one channel to reach its organizational goals. Corporate blogging normally serves multiple potential marketing goals, from driving awareness, to providing certain information, to building up relationship. The advantage of corporate blogs is that posts and comments are easy to reach and follow due to centralized hosting and generally structured conversation threads. On a corporate blog, employees, teams, or spokespersons share their personal views on certain topics. These topics can be from technical or from business nature. The corporate blog is often used to announce new products, to explain and clarify policies, or to react on certain issues. It also allows a window to the company culture and is often treated more informally than traditional press releases, though a corporate blog often tries to accomplish similar goals as press releases do.

sect1.title: Prerequisites for a &sbp;
sect1.para: The main purpose for a &sbp; is not to add work to the Documentation team, but to make knowledge that already exists in written form in other departments easily accessible for a broader internal and/or external audience.
Thus, the main content for a &sbp; paper is not delivered by the SUSE documentation team, but it usually comes from:

listitem.para: Consulting
Presales Engineers
Support
Partners
and in limited occasions also from Engineering

sect1.para: One reason why the SUSE documentation team cannot deliver the content is that we cannot reproduce the scenarios and environments implemented at our customers sites. We heavily rely on the know-how and operating experience of these colleagues that are working directly with our partners or customers.

Minimum 80 percent of a proposed or requested topic already need to be available in written form. Before starting with a new project, subject matter experts who worked together with a partner or customer on the implementation of the topic need to be defined, and they need to be committed to work on the paper together with the documentation team. All &sbp; are written in English only.

sect1.title: Request of and Contribution to SUSE Best Practices

sect2.title: How to request a &sbp;
sect2.para:
A &sbp; document has to be officially requested via an entry in
FATE
Bugzilla

The entry has to contain:
A working title
A description of the required topics
The name(s) of the subject matter expert(s)
The attachment of any existing documents
Information if the solution described has already been implemented successfully at a customers site
Only in exceptional cases, for example where partners or customers without access to FATE or Bugzilla are involved, we accept requests via an email to Meike.Chabowski@suse.com.

sect2.title: Contribution of Partners and Customers
sect2.para: Partners and Customers can also request a &sbp;, and participate in the creation of a paper. Same requirements apply as for internal requestors.

sect2.title: openSUSE
sect2.para: We accept also requests for a &sbp; for openSUSE. However, a topic requested for openSUSE may not conflict with any SUSE Linux Enterprise product related topics.

sect2.title: Selection of Topics
sect2.para: The SUSE documentation team maintains a list of proposed topics on a Trello board and decides about the relevance and priority of all requests. Customer-relevant topics will have higher priority.

sect1.title: How does the SUSE Documentation Team support
sect1.para: The SUSE documentation team is coordinating all requests for topics and updates. What’s more, the team

listitem.para: helps with finalizing the content where needed via face-to-face and phone interviews and email conversations
correct wording and fine-tuning of the content where needed
makes the content "anonymous"
ports the content into the formal "layout" of SUSE documents and rewrites the content in DocBookXML
edits the content
cares for proofreading in English
Publishes the final paper on a SUSE public webpage / portal
Promotes the paper via several channels

sect1.para: For writing the actual documents, the SUSE documentation team uses the official SUSE documentation workflow:

DocBookXML: The documentation team writes all content to be published in DocBook XML. It is based on the eXtensible Markup Language (XML) and defines the content in a semantic way through elements like in HTML. This makes changes and updates easier. In addition, the SUSE Best Practices use the same look-and-feel as the SUSE product documentation.

DocBook Authoring and Publishing Suite (DAPS): DAPS is a command-line tool the SUSE documentation team uses to generate output formats from the XML sources. SUSE Best Practices will usually be provided as single HTML, PDF and ePub. DAPS also allows to implement a modular structure for a collection of papers related to a specific topic. It allows to run some other tasks related to writing and editing, such as spell checker and the SUSE documentation style checker.

Git: Git is the main version control system for the SUSE product documentation in general, GitHub is used as a hosting server for the sources. For the &sbp;, we also use GitHub to host the sources, to enable for collaboration with contributors spread over different locations. Initially, we will work with public repositories (see also ).

sect1.title: What the Documentation Team does NOT do for SUSE Best Practices
sect1.para: To emphasize it again, the SUSE Documentation team is not delivering or writing the general content for a &sbp;. The documentation team will not test any described scenario or implementation, or validate the provided content, as it can not reproduce the scenarios.

For the same reasons, the documentation team is notresponsible for delivering the content for updates of a SUSE Best Practices paper. &sbp; are provided in English. The documentation team does not care for translation in any other language.

sect1.title: &sbp; Layout and Style
sect1.para: The layout and style of &sbp; should lean on the official style guidelines and existing stylesheets. Our language and structure specifications are listed in the Style Guide. The guide provides answers to writing, style, and layout questions commonly arising when editing SUSE documentation. Keeping a certain standard and following our style specifications makes our documentation more understandable and easier to translate. However, the &sbp; do not necessarily need to fulfill the guidelines by 100 percent and provide for more flexibility regarding their language.

The &sbp; layout differs from a usual article and will be structured as follows:
Title page, contains
Name of the series &sbp;
Title
Subtitle
Names of products involved in the solution or set up
Author(s) details (full name, title, company)
Date of publication
SUSE logo
Partner company logo (if needed)
Second page, contains
Abstract of content
Table of content
Content body
License information

The language style of a &sbp; adheres to the SUSE Styleguide. The sentence structure should be clear and concicse. Abbreviations and contractions should be avoided. The &sbp; are written in direct speech, they address the user, first person perspective must be avoided. However, the style of a &sbp; can be from a more narrative nature as a documentation article or book.
The &sbp; can include more graphical elements than a manual might contain. To ensure that all graphical elements can be displayed well in all different output formats, the following rules apply:

listitem.para: Screenshots should be provided in PNG format.
Charts, graphics and other drawings should be provided in high resolution SVG format.
Images and pictures should be provided as high resolution JPEG, TIFF, or GIF files.
Computer outputs should not be provided as screenshots, but should be written down. This makes updates or changes easier.

sect1.title: Updates
sect1.para: The content for updates of a &sbp; generally has to come from the original content deliverer, or from another subject matter expert familiar with the topic, defined in advance.

Based on the availability of information for the topic, the documentation team decides if a &sbp; will be updated or not. Also, the documentation team decides about removing a published paper from the official portal when the information seems to be outdated, and no subject matter expert volunteers to update the existing content.

sect1.title: License
sect1.para: Usually, all SUSE documentation is published under an open document license, such as the GNU Free Documentation License , or the Creative Commons .

This is also the case for the &sbp;. However, we reserve the right to change the copyright of a &sbp; to a proprietary license in cases where a key contributor has valid reasons to require this, or where we see the exigency to do so to protect SUSE´s business. In the latter case, the paper will be published under SUSE Copyright.

sect1.title: Recognition of authors
sect1.para: SUSE does not pay an author or contributor for the delivery of content for a paper. However, the efforts for the contribution to a &sbp; should be recognized by several means.
The following appreciation appears on the &sbp;:

listitem.para: Key content providers for &sbp; will be highlighted as authors of the published document. On the paper, there will be published their full name, job title, and company.
If a paper is written in co-authorship with another company, the logo of the partner company will be printed on the title page of the &sbp; paper, in addition to the SUSE logo.
Key contributors to a &sbp; will receive a SUSE or openSUSE branded limited edition merchandise item.

sect1.para: In addition to the above, we provide incentives for collaboration on &sbp;. The main writers of a SUSE Best Practices will receive a special (limited) SUSE or openSUSE branded merchandise item as acknowledgment for their efforts. These items can be but are not limited to:

listitem.para: Special edition of T-Shirts
Technical gadgets
SUSE Logo as plush animal

sect1.para: In a first step, we will give away a SUSE Logo plush animal (Geeko) of one meter of size.

sect1.title: Distribution and Promotion of &sbp;
sect1.para: &sbp; documents will be published on an official SUSE Website (currently this is the SUSE Documentation webpage at ). They will be publicly made available to everyone interested in reading these documents. SUSE will reserve the right to give limited access to particular papers as a value add only to registered customers, via the SUSE Customer Center. We plan to develop and implement a Portal for the &sbp;, where in future all papers of this series will be posted. Details for the portal are work in progress.

&sbp; will be promoted extensively via different Social Media Channels, such as
Twitter
SUSE Blogs at
Facebook
Google+

A subset of &sbp; will also be used for broader Marketing purposes, such as email or online programs or company-wide and product overaching campaigns. You can find examples of online campaigns and programs here:
SUSE Manager program
Zero Downtime campaign

sect1.title: Open Items
sect1.para: Some open items are still to be clarified. For certain questions, a company decision might be needed.

sect2.title: Convincing the Teams that Have to Deliver the Content
sect2.para: As most of the content for the &sbp; needs to come from teams outside the Enginnering departments, for example from Consulting, Support, Allliances or Sales, we need to get the buy-in from the respective directors and team leads.

Most of them in direct conversations already agreed that content as planned to be provided with the &sbp; is needed and required by customers. However, the challenge is to transform the consense into a commitment.

This commitment needs to be twofold:
The directors and team leads need to understand that for the &sbp; we need to work with documentation that in big parts has been created for projects or proof of concepts for a specific customer. In general, we are not allowed to use project-specific material for public purposes, and if we ask customers directly if they allow us to use the material, many of them will object to it.
One way to circumvent this hurdle is to include an official clause with our consulting and sales contracts, which declares that project or customer documentation might be reused in anonymized manner for SUSE documentation purposes.
The management level of Consulting, Support, Alliances and Sales need to free up some time of their team members for work on &sbp;.

We will only get the commitment if we succeed to make the stakeholders in Consulting, Support, Alliances and Sales understand that the &sbp; represent a win-win situation. They will not hurt their customers, but benefit existing as well as potential new customers. In addition, they help our colleagues from these departments to save time as they don´t have to reinvent the wheel for many projects because they can rely on accessible documentation.

The question is now how to approach the stakeholders from these departments? Should we approach them bottom-up or top-down? Do we talk to them ourselves in a first step, or do we ask our SUSE Senior Leadership team to approach them? If we decide for the bottom-up approach, can we secure backing from the Senior Leadership Team to put some pressure on them?

sect2.title: Communication and Promotion of &sbp;
sect2.para: First of all, we need to get official approval for the &sbp; from the ELT. A presentation about the &sbp; needs to be created for this purpose. We already have buy-in from our CTO Thomas Di Giacomo.
To communicate the &sbp; internally and promote them externally, we need to work with the Marketing departments.

Before we can make anything public, we need to have a conversation with Jo Harris and her directors, and get their buy-in, too. Mainly Product Marketing provides high level technical whitepapers. We need to make Marketing understand that we do not compete with them by providing additonal whitepapers, but that we deliver additional material which they can also use for Marketing purposes and which nobody provided so far via streamlined processes.
After that conversation took place, we should cooperate with Marketing to communicate the &sbp; to our colleagues. There are several channels:

listitem.para: Every 1st Tuesday of a month, the SUSE Marketing department has an extended Marketing meeting via phone. We can ask to be invited to that meeting to introduce the &sbp; to the Marketing groups.

Marketing provides a monthly newsletter for customer- and partner facing departments inside SUSE, with relevant information and links. We can ask them to include the information about the &sbp; to that newsletter.

Internal SUSE-wide newsbriefs are distributed via email to all employees. They are created and distributed under responsibility of MarCom. To send out a SUSE-wide newsbrief, we need to get approval from Jo Harris. Scott Corfield can help us to set up the newsbrief.

To reach especially all our Sales teams, we can work with Rich Wiltbank from Sales Enablement on an announcement or a Field Memo via the Sales Enablement mailinglis, or a presentation slot within the series of Sales Enablement webinars.
To get our partners on board, we need to work with the Alliances teams to get a slot on their regular update calls.

sect2.para: After the interal communication took place, we need to promote the &sbp; to the public. Again, we need to use multiple channels to push awareness for the &sbp;:

listitem.para: Social media channels, including Twitter, SUSE communities and blogs, Facebook, LinkedIn, Google+,
Official SUSE Press Release or News Item, via our PR managers Kevan Barney and Vera Schneider. Rob Ahern is the Director for PR and MarCom and should be involved early.
Marketing sends out a montly newsletter to the entire SUSE customer database. Scott Corfield is responsible for the external newsletter. We can request to get an article in one of the next items.

sect2.title: Budget
sect2.para: We don´t pay for content contribution, but we’ve got feedback from the field that as a “stimulus”, the key authors/contributors for an SBP should receive a special/limited SUSE Merchandise item. In a first step, we have ordered huge plush SUSE Geekos.

But we need to decide/define as soon as possible how to proceed after we ran out of stock. Also, if an author contributes to more than one paper, we should provide a different item as recognition. Thus we should be prepared for additional incentives.

listitem.para: The idea is to create individual T-Shirts, produced on a per needbasis.
The cost is roughly 20 Euro per item.
Thus we should plan with roughly 500 Euro for additional incentives.

sect2.para: There is a budget for the translation of documentation, but this budget is calculated only for proofreading and translating the proper product documentation SUSE Best Practices will be published in English, translations are not planned. However, to ensure the quality of the SBP’s regarding proper language, we need to make sure that we will have a budget available for proofreading I have approached our translation coordinator for a quote.

From our translation service provider, we got a quote for proofreading:
Proofreading costs us 70 Euro per 20 pages.
Minimum order value is 70 Euro/20 pages.
We can accumulate shorter papers to match the minimum order of 20 pages.
For FY17, we estimate we will to work on 20 &sbp; documents with an average length of 20 pages.
This means we need a budget of roughly Euro 1,500 for proofreading.

sect2.title: Collaboration Platforms
sect2.para: Collaboration space for topic list: Currently we maintain the general list for topics on Trello. Is this the right place to make sure all stakeholders and decision makers for &sbp; have access? Which other tools exist that might be suitable?

Collaboration space for writers/subject matter experts: We need to define which platform we use for collaboration with our contributors, no matter if internal or external. Currently, our repository for &sbp; is a public repositors on GitHub. Do we need to provide a private space, too? Or should we decide about this topic when the request for a private collaboration space comes up.

sect2.title: &sbp; Portal
sect2.para: For the &sbp;, we plan to implement a specific portal built for this new series of documents. We still need to discuss the requirements and parameters of the portal.
